title.narrative: Emergency Response to Drought in Honduras

description.narrative:
Honduras has been suffering from 4 years of drought. This has applied significant pressure on poor farming communities. Relief has been felt in 2019 with rains returning to some departments, but departments in the Dry Corridor have seen considerable crop losses year over year. This has had severe detrimental effects on families’ food and nutrition, while eating away at families’ overall resilience and ability to bounce back. Individuals in the 7 most vulnerable departments of the Dry Corridor are at extreme risk as:
- families have exhausted their food stocks.
- Have had very poor yields from the January harvest.
- Rain is not forecasted and water levels have reduced by as much as 83%.
- The first agricultural season of 2020 is only harvested in August.
- Not included in the list of municipalities targeted by the UN CERF.
This significant extension of the lean season will hit families in the Dry Corridor the hardest, with the peak of the crisis in March-April 2020. START Anticipation funding in February would allow the provision of vital assistance to households at risk of extreme food insecurity; ensuring access to basic foods, helping farmers prepare for the next harvest through cash or vouchers or the distribution of drought-resistant seeds and the supply of non-essential complementary foods (such as salt, sugar, oil). Preventing the adoption of further negative coping strategies is crucial in this highly disaster-prone area.
